title: @YasuoHaters

It's ridiculous how much of an advantage yasuo has against ranged champions let alone those who fully rely on skill shots. 
Look at this way, he has an infinite number of dashes amongst a minion wave granting him insane mobility.
His flow grants him a shield automatically which just flat out negates damage and generates in combat. 
No resource whatsoever.
Double scaling crit chance making it viable just to build two crit items and then whatever tanky items or sustain items you want.

And finally he is one of the few champions that can actually get a kill simply because your minions were coming to lane. 

Put it this way, if I play say for example {{champion:26}} it is not just hard to land my stun it becomes an utter freaking miracle to land my stun on a {{champion:157}} because it's even harder to punish him for a mistake that isn't simply overextending.

That is what makes his kit though, He is built like that like an agile Samurai. That makes Yasuo, Yasuo. Without his Dash and Windwall. He'd be just a normal champ with no unique game style. Like many of the champs in League

The vast majority of champions have a unique styled attuned to them such as {{champion:202}} or {{champion:136}} . I think its flawed to assume there couldn't have been another direction especially with his crit passive or the fact he generates a shield that absorbs all damage dealt to him in a single hit. 

He's a champion designed with counterplay in mind to his opponents but leaving a number of champions without the same options when against him.

Recently the champs have been getting unique gamestyle but all the old champs E.G. {{champion:84}} {{champion:39}} {{champion:27}} {{champion:24}}. But recently the champs are more thought out and seem to be designed better

{{champion:27}} 's gamestyle, is probably the most unique in the whole game. His entire playstyle revolves around killing people by running away... 

Thats pretty fuckin unique.

Ahhh ok i see the confusion here!

You've heard people say "Yasuo has a **high** skill ceiling" and thought 'This means i need skill to play my champ'
but what it actually means is 'In order to play Yasuo to his **full potential** you need to be very good.' and thats true.
but he also has a very very **low** skill floor. which means you can perform **well enough** with Yasuo even if you're quite bad.

This means that you need to be Faker to play Yasuo to 100% of his potential, but you can be a vegetable and still play him at 95% of his potential. 

(You're an AD champion with no mana, infinite dashes, 100% crit, a passive shield, a wall that blocks 70% of the harmful abilities in the game and an ult that OTHER PEOPLE can activate for you.... Look at that, and tell me the champ is going to be hard... come on, that champion basically plays itself.)

Also before you call me a 'Yasuo Hater' I was a Yas main since the day he came out till quite recently when a more interesting champ came out. and he's still my go-to AD mid laner.

I think it takes a lot more than statistics to single handedly prove a point however it's apparent to me Yasuo is quite overloaded.

The ability to dash once per target within a given duration, low cooldowns on abilities, hard CC which in contrast allows him to directly apply his ultimate which deals high amounts of damage which causes Yasuo to specifically ignore armour. He also gains a shield which can negate a large portion of damage once while also scaling twice as much in crit as any champion allowing him always to maintain a degree of relevancy simply because his high power curves. He has a strong early game and scales very well into late game. 

That while Yasuo's weakness being in the form of crowd control does exist and that because of that he is weak against some match ups like {{champion:39}} and {{champion:90}} a huge portion of stuns and snares and even some slows exist as ranged skillshots which is countered by Yasuo's wind wall. 


Finally, survivability isn't just a measurement of said Yasuo skill but actually also a test of whether or not the player is good in general because a good portion of people can pick up Yasuo and play him a few times and already make "good plays" with him just by understanding the basic fundamentals of Yasuo's kit.

Problem with your argument is that if most Yasuo's do in fact feed in the majority of the games they play then his winrate should theoretically much lower but that's simply not true.  You're trying to redirect the point towards the skill of an actual player as if it actually reflects the strength of a champion which is an argumentative fallacy given the statistics and how strong Yasuo actually is.  Personally I wouldn't go around pretending that overextending, misplaying and being killed for a too early of an engage is a reflection of Yasuo's abilities as it actually a reflection of a player's skills and map awareness in general.

no, i do agree with you here, yes riven does need skill, but unlike yasuo, she has much more room for error, seeing as she had spells with low cd, a shield thats 800+ on a 3.6 sec cd, and multiple forms of no miss cc, but to play her well you do need skill for animation canceling.

Yasuo is in a similar boat, yes even the worst players can use him, but unlike using riven or zed they will do absolutely nothing but press r if they have a knockup and then proceed to die after doing nothing.

The key difference between Riven and Yasuo is that if you pick Riven you have to snowball. She is the literal definition of a feast of famine champion where you are rather useless if you're not ahead but if you pick yasuo you scale rather well compared to most laners regardless of how fed you become as long as you CS properly.

If you pick Riven you literally run the risk of not snowballing and in fact providing nothing for your team except for being a possibly major burden or your snowball and dominate till mid to late game and while not to say that the champion is bad I personally would not pick a Riven unless I really wanted to played her because she is not necessarily an ideal candidate. 

Another thing is that even if Yasuo fell behind he could still scale well into mid game simply because he will most likely reach 100% crit before anyone else and will still be able to deal a lot of damage to a squishy of a given type. His ultimate allows him to fit into team compositions with champions such as malphite, Janna, Rek'sai, Alistar, Nautilus, Velkoz, Xin Zhao, etc whose knock up is much easier to land if you're struggling would be able to uplift the restriction on his ultimate basically suspending them in mid air for a whole second more and dealing heavy damage.

Like i said, Yasuo takes skill to play him very well, but to play him just averagely well takes very very little skill.

The main thing that makes Yasuo more difficult to play is controlling his dash, so lets remove that dash for a minute, 
ALL of his other abilities require no skill at all: You place W so you take no damage, spam Q on your enemy until you get a hurricane, hit something with the hurricane, press R and repeat. Thats like Garen level mechanics.

Riven is the same as Yasuo, High skill ceiling (not as high as Yas but higher than many other champs) and very low skill floor, 
Top tier Riven players destroy lanes with animation cancelling and all that, where first time Rivens just press all her buttons in whatever order they want and still do well.

I'm gonna put this in terms of effective health

According to the wiki 
"A unit with 60 armor has 60% more of its maximum health in effective health, so if the unit has 1000 maximum health, it will take 1600 physical damage to kill it."

Average adc according to stats above: 1924 x 1.788 = 3440.112 effective health

My point is, that during a fight, you auto attack the enemy at some point right? so all the time between aiming abilities, the computer is helping you out.

Mages dont have any of their damage controlled by the computer, the player has to aim every ability.
Yas has to aim 3 abilities, and the computer gets to deal damage as quick as it can when you arent aiming them.
Mages have to aim 4 abilities, and the computer doesn't help at all.

AD champions always have en advantage over AP champions because they are aided by the computer. 
(im not saying AP champions are weaker than AD ones, I'm saying they have a disadvantage.)
